articles.headline: Obama Details Lines of Battle in Budget Plan, and on Libya
articles.snippet: In his first news conference in eight months, President Obama signaled he would grapple with Republicans over tax rates and the handling of the attack on Americans in Benghazi.
articles.abstract: In his first news conference in eight months, President Obama signaled he would grapple with Republicans over tax rates and the handling of the attack on Americans in Benghazi.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, riding the winds of re-election, signaled Wednesday that he was prepared to battle with Republicans over budget negotiations and his national security team’s handling of the deadly attack on an American mission in Libya.

articles.headline: Making Small Business a Cause
articles.snippet: Jim Koch, founder of the Boston Beer Company, and his employees have teamed up with a microlender to hold “speed coaching” sessions for fledgling food, beverage and hospitality businesses.
articles.abstract: Jim Koch, founder of the Boston Beer Company, and his employees have teamed up with a microlender to hold “speed coaching” sessions for fledgling food, beverage and hospitality businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlene O’Garro’s cake business was barely a month old when she arrived at the Samuel Adams brewery in South Boston recently to meet with business counselors, but she brought with her an agenda that hinted at outsize ambitions.

articles.headline: 2 Wristbands Keep Tabs on Fitness
articles.snippet: Exercise lovers, your worries are over. Or some of them are, because Jawbone and Nike are introducing new wearable, accelerometer-based fitness-tracking bands.
articles.abstract: Exercise lovers, your worries are over. Or some of them are, because Jawbone and Nike are introducing new wearable, accelerometer-based fitness-tracking bands.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve heard: Americans are becoming less fit and more fat. There are all kinds of theories about why — bigger meal portions, omnipresent corn syrup and sugar, fewer pickup stickball games after school. But people are starting to think that in many cases, body weight might somehow be linked to diet and exercise.

articles.headline: Caffeinated Drink Cited in Reports of 13 Deaths
articles.snippet: A high-caffeine energy drink, 5-Hour Energy, has been cited as possibly being involved in 13 deaths, according to Food and Drug Administration records.
articles.abstract: A high-caffeine energy drink, 5-Hour Energy, has been cited as possibly being involved in 13 deaths, according to Food and Drug Administration records.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal officials have received reports of 13 deaths over the last four years that cited the possible involvement of 5-Hour Energy, a highly caffeinated energy shot, according to Food and Drug Administration records and an interview with an agency official.

articles.headline: Veteran F.B.I. Agent Helped Start Petraeus E-Mail Inquiry
articles.snippet: Frederick W. Humphries II, a counterterrorism agent, took the initial complaint from Jill Kelley about e-mails accusing  her of inappropriate behavior toward David H. Petraeus.
articles.abstract: Frederick W. Humphries II, a counterterrorism agent, took the initial complaint from Jill Kelley about e-mails accusing  her of inappropriate behavior toward David H. Petraeus.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOVER, Fla. — The F.B.I. agent who spurred the investigation that led to the resignation of David H. Petraeus as C.I.A. director is a “hard-charging” veteran who helped investigate the foiled millennium terrorist plot in 1999, colleagues said on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Scott Shane and Alain Delaquérière

articles.headline: Greece Examines a Debt Buyback as One Way to Reduce Its Burden
articles.snippet: Lawyers and bankers are suggesting that Greece offer a buyback of its debt, and possibly invoke clauses in its bond contracts to put pressure on debt holders to accept the offer.
articles.abstract: Lawyers and bankers are suggesting that Greece offer a buyback of its debt, and possibly invoke clauses in its bond contracts to put pressure on debt holders to accept the offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Greece’s creditors bicker over the terms of its bailout, the government is examining a more radical approach that could reduce the country’s escalating debt pile in one fell swoop.

articles.headline: F.H.A. Audit Said to Show Low Reserves
articles.snippet: Escalating losses on the home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration are said to be depleting its capital reserves, leaving it billions short of projections.
articles.abstract: Escalating losses on the home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration are said to be depleting its capital reserves, leaving it billions short of projections.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Housing Administration’s annual report is expected to show a sharp deterioration in the agency’s financial condition, including a shortfall in reserves, the result of escalating losses on the $1.1 trillion in mortgages that it insures, according to people with knowledge of the entity’s operations.

articles.headline: Obama Meets C.E.O.’s as Fiscal Reckoning Nears
articles.snippet: Without offering new policy details, the president used a White House meeting to rebuild his relationship with business leaders.
articles.abstract: Without offering new policy details, the president used a White House meeting to rebuild his relationship with business leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama extended an olive branch to business leaders Wednesday, seeking their support as he prepared to negotiate with Congressional Republicans over the fiscal impasse in Washington.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Crises at BBC Brought Rules, Then a Failure
articles.snippet: The corporation established elaborate procedures that placed more formal responsibility for delicate decisions in the hands not of individual managers, but of rigid hierarchies.
articles.abstract: The corporation established elaborate procedures that placed more formal responsibility for delicate decisions in the hands not of individual managers, but of rigid hierarchies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was 2004, and the British Broadcasting Corporation was gripped by a crisis over journalistic standards that had led to Parliamentary hearings, public recrimination and the resignations of its two top officials. Vowing change, the corporation established elaborate bureaucratic procedures that placed more formal responsibility for delicate decisions in the hands not of individual managers, but of rigid hierarchies.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Israel and Hamas Step Up Air Attacks in Gaza Clash
articles.snippet: Israel on Friday said it was prepared to pause its assault during a visit by Egypt’s prime minister, a day after Palestinian militants fired hundreds of rockets and Israeli tanks rumbled toward the Gaza border.
articles.abstract: Israel on Friday said it was prepared to pause its assault during a visit by Egypt’s prime minister, a day after Palestinian militants fired hundreds of rockets and Israeli tanks rumbled toward the Gaza border.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRYAT MALACHI, Israel — Israel and Hamas brushed aside international calls for restraint on Thursday and escalated their lethal conflict over Gaza, where Palestinian militants launched hundreds of rockets into Israeli territory, targeting Tel Aviv for the first time, and Israel intensified its aerial assaults and sent armored vehicles rumbling toward the Gaza border for a possible invasion.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: BP Will Plead Guilty and Pay Over $4 Billion
articles.snippet: The British oil company said it had agreed to pay fines and accept charges related to the rig explosion two years ago that killed 11 people and caused a giant oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.abstract: The British oil company said it had agreed to pay fines and accept charges related to the rig explosion two years ago that killed 11 people and caused a giant oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — BP, the British oil company, said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay $4.5 billion in fines and other penalties and to plead guilty to 14 criminal charges related to the rig explosion two years ago that killed 11 people and caused a giant oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Inquiry Reflects Alarm on Corruption
articles.snippet: An inquiry is now looking at activities in Brazil, China and India, along with Mexico, Wal-Mart said. Its quarterly results showed lower-than-expected sales.
articles.abstract: An inquiry is now looking at activities in Brazil, China and India, along with Mexico, Wal-Mart said. Its quarterly results showed lower-than-expected sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart on Thursday reported that its investigation into violations of a federal antibribery law had extended beyond Mexico to China, India and Brazil, some of the retailer’s most important international markets.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and David Barstow

articles.headline: House Report Faults MF Global Regulators
articles.snippet: The report from Congressional Republicans describes a “disorganized and haphazard” approach to oversight in the week before MF Global spun out of control. The report says the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the S.E.C. failed to coordinate...
articles.abstract: The report from Congressional Republicans describes a “disorganized and haphazard” approach to oversight in the week before MF Global spun out of control. The report says the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the S.E.C. failed to coordinate as the firm was on the brink.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced
